channel.description: Recent content on My Tech Knowledge Notes

item.title: Cloud Networking & Zero-Trust Interview Guide
item.description:
A comprehensive deep-dive into the four pillars of modern cloud networking:

üü¢ 1. Protocol & Layer Troubleshooting.
üü° 2. Connectivity & Routing.
üîµ 3. Cloud Security & Zero-Trust.
üî¥ 4. Identity & Microservices.

This guide provides a systematic framework for diagnosing failures where networking ends and identity begins. Use these mental models and ASCII diagrams to master your next technical deep-dive or architectural review.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Scenario:

"Ping works but application traffic fails."

item.title: Kubernetes Production Issues
item.description:
Kubernetes Production Issues (Most Common ‚Üí Rare & Critical)

1Ô∏è‚É£ Pods Stuck in CrashLoopBackOff (MOST COMMON)

Symptoms

  • Pod keeps restarting
  • Application never becomes healthy

Common Causes

  • App crashes on startup
  • Wrong environment variables
  • Dependency unavailable (DB, API)
  • Incorrect command/args

Troubleshooting Steps

kubectl get pods
kubectl describe pod <pod>
kubectl logs <pod>
kubectl logs <pod> --previous

Production Fix

  • Fix application config
  • Add readiness/liveness probes
  • Add retries & graceful error handling
  • Use initContainers for dependencies

Interview Tip

item.title: Zero-Trust in Cloud: PrivateLink + IAM
item.description:
This page explains how Zero-Trust is implemented in the cloud using PrivateLink and IAM.

It shows why private network access alone is not sufficient and how identity and policy enforcement control access.

PrivateLink reduces network exposure, while IAM ensures authentication and authorization per request. Together, they form a true Zero-Trust architecture.

1Ô∏è‚É£ The Core Zero-Trust Rule (Cloud Version)

Network reachability ‚â† access

In Zero-Trust cloud:

  • Private IP does not mean trusted
  • VPC peering does not mean trusted
  • Only identity + policy grants access

2Ô∏è‚É£ What Problem PrivateLink Solves

Without PrivateLink (Traditional)

item.title: Phase 3 : TCP/IP and ports
item.description:
This phase is where networking becomes practical and real. We focus on how data actually moves between devices.

You‚Äôll learn why TCP and UDP exist, how ports work, and how reliable and fast communication is achieved between clients and servers in the real world.

1Ô∏è‚É£ Why TCP/IP Exists

IP (Layer 3) can only do one thing:

  • Deliver packets from one IP to another IP

Problems with IP alone:

  • No guarantee of delivery
  • No ordering of packets
  • No error recovery

Because of these limitations, we need Transport Layer protocols.

item.title: Phase 4 ‚Äì DNS (Domain Name System)
item.description:
DNS is one of the most critical systems on the internet.

If DNS fails, everything appears broken ‚Äî even when the network is perfectly fine.

In this phase, we focus on DNS ‚Äî the quiet system that makes the internet usable for humans.

You‚Äôll learn how domain names are translated into IP addresses, what actually happens when you type a website into your browser, and how DNS queries move across multiple servers behind the scenes.

item.title: Phase 5 : Routing, Gateway and NAT
item.description:
Phase 5 focuses on how networks communicate.

It covers routing, which directs traffic between networks; gateways, which connect different network types; and NAT (Network Address Translation), which lets multiple devices share a single IP while keeping internal addresses private.

1Ô∏è‚É£ What Is Routing?

Definition:

Routing is the process of deciding where to send a packet next.

Every packet asks:

‚ÄúHow do I reach this destination IP?‚Äù

The answer comes from a routing table.

item.title: Phase 6 : Firewall and Network Security Basics
item.description:
Phase 6 is where you learn why traffic is allowed or blocked. Most real outages live here.

This phase introduces the fundamentals of network security, focusing on how firewalls control and protect traffic.

It explains basic security rules, filtering concepts, and how networks defend against unauthorized access and common threats.

1Ô∏è‚É£ What Is a Firewall?

Simple definition:

A firewall is a traffic filter.

It decides:

  • Who can talk
  • To whom
  • On which port
  • Using which protocol

Nothing more, nothing less.

item.title: Phase 7 : End-to-End Troubleshooting Mental Model
item.description:
This phase builds a structured way of thinking for diagnosing network issues.

It emphasizes tracing problems step-by-step from source to destination, helping you quickly isolate, analyze, and resolve real-world connectivity issues.

1Ô∏è‚É£ The One Mental Model (Memorize This)

Networking problems are always caused by a break in the path.

Your job is to find where the path breaks.

2Ô∏è‚É£ The End-to-End Path (Always Think Like This)

     Client
       ‚Üì
     DNS
       ‚Üì
     Routing
       ‚Üì
     Firewall
       ‚Üì
     Host Interface
       ‚Üì
     Service (Port)

If it fails anywhere ‚Üí connection fails.

item.title: Phase 2 : IP and Subnetting
item.description:
In this phase, we explore IP addresses and subnetting ‚Äî the part of networking that explains how devices are identified and grouped together.

You‚Äôll understand what IP addresses represent, why networks are divided into subnets, and how this structure makes large networks possible and manageable.

IP Addresses (The Heart of Networking)

What Is an IP Address

An IP address is a logical identifier that tells the network:

  • Who you are
  • Where you are

Example: 192.168.1.10

item.title: Phase 1 : Core networking concepts
item.description:
In this phase, we build the foundation of networking by understanding what networks are and how devices communicate.

You‚Äôll learn what hosts, IP addresses, clients, and servers really mean, and how simple request‚Äìresponse communication powers almost everything on the internet.

1Ô∏è‚É£ What Is a Network?

Simple definition:

A network is a group of devices that can communicate with each other.

Examples of devices:

  • Laptop
  • Phone
  • Server
  • Printer
  • Router

“If devices can send and receive data, they are on a network.”

item.title: Content Delivery Network (CDN): Beginner to SRE-Level Complete Guide
item.description: A complete CDN guide from basics to advanced SRE concepts with diagrams, use cases, examples, and 20 interview Q&A.

item.description: A concise comparison of Redis and Memcached with real-life scenarios and 20 must-know interview questions.

item.title: Browser Caching
item.description:
What is browser caching?

Broswer caching is a technique where the web browser stores copies of website files (HTML, CSS, Javacsript, images, etc .) on the user’s device so that the website loads faster on future visits.

Use Case

  • Faster page loads
  • Reduced bandwith
  • Lower serve load
  • Better user experience

How browser caching works?

Browser follow rules sent by the server using HTTP headers that tell them:

  • What to cache
  • How long to cache
  • Whether to re-check the server

Cache control headers

  • Cache-Control: max-age -> Cache for X seconds
  • Cache-Control: no-cache -> Re-check with server before use
  • Cache-Control: no-store -> Don’t store anything
  • Expires -> Absolute expiration date
  • ETag -> Version identifier

Cahing Flow (Simple)

  1. Brwoser -> Server: “Give me the Page”
  2. Server -> Browser: Page + Cache rules
  3. Browser: Saves files locally
  4. Next visit:
    • If fresh -> load from cache
    • If expired -> Ask server

üí° Final memory trick

  • Cache = Speed
  • No-cache = Freshness
  • No-store = Security

Clearing cache

Deletes stored files -> forces browser to download fresh content.

item.title: Cache invalidation
item.description:
What is Cache Invalidation?

Cache invalidation is the process of removing or updating cached data before it naturally expires, when the original data changes ‚Äî so users don‚Äôt see outdated (‚Äústale‚Äù) information.

Goal: Always serve fresh and correct data, not stale cached copies.

Why Is It Hard?

  • In distributed systems, the same data can be cached in many places (servers, CDNs, browsers).
  • Making sure every copy is updated at the right time is complex.

‚ÄúThere are only two hard things in Computer Science: cache invalidation and naming things.‚Äù
